Welcome to REST Api HW_14_GoIT’s documentation!¶

REST API main¶

main.healthchecker(db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The healthchecker function is a simple function that checks the health of the database. It does this by making a request to the database and checking if it returns any results. If there are no results, then we know something is wrong with our connection to the database.

Parameters:

db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

async main.startup()¶

The startup function is called when the application starts up. It’s a good place to initialize things that are needed by your app, such as caches or databases.

Returns:

A fastapilimiter instance

REST API database Connect¶

my_contacts.database.db_connect.get_db()¶

The get_db function is a context manager that returns the database session. It also ensures that the connection to the database is closed after each request.

Returns:

A database session

class my_contacts.schemas.ContactModel(*, first_name: str, last_name: str, email: EmailStr | None, phone_number: PhoneNumber, birthday: PastDate | None, position: str | None)¶

first_name (str): The first name of the contact. last_name (str): The last name of the contact. email (Optional[EmailStr]): The email address of the contact (optional). phone_number (PhoneNumber): The phone number of the contact. birthday (Optional[PastDate]): The birthday of the contact (optional). position (Optional[str]): The position of the contact (optional).

REST API repository Contacts¶

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.create_contact(body: ContactModel, user: User, db: Session) → Contact¶

The create_contact function creates a new contact in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – ContactModel: Validate the incoming data

  • user – User: Get the user id of the logged in user

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A contact object

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.delete_contact(contact_id: int, user: User, db: Session)¶
The delete_contact function deletes a contact from the database.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to be deleted. user (User): The user who is deleting the contact. This is used to ensure that only contacts belonging

to this particular user are deleted, and not all contacts with this id in general.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact to be deleted

  • user – User: Get the user_id from the token

  • db – Session: Access the database and delete the contact

Returns:

A string with the name of the deleted contact

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.get_contact(contact_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Type[Contact] | None¶

The get_contact function takes in a contact_id and user object, and returns the Contact object with that id. If no such contact exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact in the database

  • user – User: Get the user_id from the database

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A contact object or none

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.get_contacts(skip: int, limit: int, user: User, db: Session) → list[Type[Contact]]¶

The get_contacts function returns a list of contacts for the user.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Skip a certain number of contacts in the database

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • user – User: Get the user_id from the logged in user

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A list of contact objects

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.get_upcoming_birthdays(days: int, user: User, db: Session) → List[Type[Contact]]¶

The get_upcoming_birthdays function returns a list of contacts whose birthdays are within the next ‘days’ days.

Parameters:

  • days – int: Determine how many days in the future we want to look for birthdays

  • user – User: Get the user’s id from the database

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

Returns:

A list of contacts with upcoming birthdays

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.patch_update_contact(contact_id: int, body: ContactUpdate, user: User, db: Session) → Type[Contact]¶
The patch_update_contact function updates a contact in the database.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to update. body (ContactUpdate): The updated information for the specified contact. user (User): The user who is making this request, used to verify that they are authorized to make this change.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact to be deleted

  • body – ContactUpdate: Get the data from the request body

  • user – User: Get the user id from the token

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

Returns:

A contact object

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.put_update_contact(contact_id: int, body: ContactModel, user: User, db: Session) → Type[Contact]¶
The put_update_contact function updates a contact in the database.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to update. body (ContactModel): The updated information for the specified contact.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Find the contact in the database

  • body – ContactModel: Pass in the json data that is sent to the api

  • user – User: Ensure that only the user who created the contact can update it

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

Returns:

The contact that has been updated

async my_contacts.repository.contacts.search_contacts(q: str, skip: int, limit: int, user: User, db: Session) → List[Type[Contact]]¶
The search_contacts function searches for contacts in the database.
Args:

q (str): The search query. skip (int): Number of contacts to be skipped. limit (int): Number of contacts to be returned.

Parameters:

  • q – str: Search for a contact in the database

  • skip – int: Skip the first n contacts

  • limit – int: Limit the number of results returned

  • user – User: Get the user’s id from the database

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A list of contacts

REST API repository Users¶

async my_contacts.repository.users.change_password(user, password: str, db: Session) → Type[User]¶
The change_password function takes a user and password, then updates the user’s password in the database.
Args:

user (User): The User object to update. password (str): The new plaintext password for this User.

Parameters:

  • user – Identify the user whose password is being changed

  • password – str: Pass in the new password to be set

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The user object

async my_contacts.repository.users.confirmed_email(email: str, db: Session) → None¶

The confirmed_email function takes in an email and a database session, and sets the confirmed field of the user with that email to True.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Get the email of the user that needs to be confirmed

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

None

  • body – UserModel: Validate the request body

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

A user object

The delete_user function deletes a user from the database.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Specify the type of the user parameter

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

None, which is the default return value for functions that don’t explicitly return a value

async my_contacts.repository.users.get_user_by_email(email: str, db: Session) → Type[User]¶

The get_user_by_email function takes in an email and a database session, and returns the user associated with that email. If no such user exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Specify the email address of the user we are trying to find

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A user object

The update_avatar function updates the avatar_url of a user in the database.

Parameters:

  • avatar_url – str: Specify the type of the parameter

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The updated user

async my_contacts.repository.users.update_token(user: Type[User], token: str | None, db: Session) → None¶

The update_token function updates the refresh token for a user.

Parameters:

  • user – Type[User]: Specify the type of the user parameter

  • token – str | None: Set the refresh token for a user

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

None, but it does update the user’s refresh token in the database

REST API routes Auth¶

async my_contacts.routes.auth.confirmed_email(token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The confirmed_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

It takes the token from the URL and uses it to get the user’s email address. Then, it checks if that user exists in our database and if they have already confirmed their email. If not, then we update their record in our database with a confirmation of their email.

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message that the email is confirmed

async my_contacts.routes.auth.get_refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The get_refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token. It takes in a refresh token and returns a new access token and a new refresh token. The function first decodes the given refresh_token, then checks if it matches with the user’s stored one. If they match, it creates two new tokens (access &amp; refresh) for that user.

Parameters:

  • credentials – HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the request header

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A new access token and a new refresh token

async my_contacts.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(OAuth2PasswordRequestForm), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The login function is used to authenticate a user.

It takes in the username and password of the user, and returns an access token if successful. The access token can be used to make authenticated requests.

Parameters:

  • body – OAuth2PasswordRequestForm: Get the username and password from the request body

  • db – Session: Get the database session from the dependency

Returns:

A token and a refresh token

async my_contacts.routes.auth.register_user(request: Request, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, body: UserModel = Depends(UserModel), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The register_user function creates a new user in the database.

It takes a UserModel object as input, which is validated by pydantic. The password is hashed using Argon2 and stored in the database. A confirmation email is sent to the user’s email address.

Parameters:

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the request

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • body – UserModel: Get the user’s information from the request body

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with two keys: user and detail

REST API routes Contacts¶

async my_contacts.routes.contacts.create_contact(body: ContactModel, current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The create_contact function creates a new contact in the database.

The function takes a ContactModel object as input, which is validated by pydantic. The current_user is retrieved from the auth_service and passed to contacts.create_contact().

Parameters:

  • body – ContactModel: Define the type of data that is expected in the request body

  • current_user – User: Get the user id of the current logged in user

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The created contact

async my_contacts.routes.contacts.delete_contact(contact_id: int, current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The delete_contact function deletes a contact from the database.

It takes in an integer representing the id of the contact to be deleted, and returns a dictionary containing information about that contact.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact to be deleted

  • current_user – User: Get the current user’s id

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A contact object

async my_contacts.routes.contacts.get_upcoming_birthdays(days: int = Query(7), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The get_upcoming_birthdays function returns a list of contacts with upcoming birthdays.

Parameters:

  • days – int: Specify the number of days in advance to get upcoming birthdays

  • description – Describe the parameter in the api documentation

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the auth_service

  • db – Session: Get a database session

Returns:

A list of contacts

async my_contacts.routes.contacts.patch_update_contact(body: ContactUpdate, contact_id: int, current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The patch_update_contact function updates a contact in the database.

The function takes in a ContactUpdate object, which is defined as follows:

Parameters:

  • body – ContactUpdate: Get the data from the request body

  • contact_id – int: Get the contact id from the url

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the auth_service

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A contact object

async my_contacts.routes.contacts.put_update_contact(body: ContactModel, contact_id: int, current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The put_update_contact function updates a contact in the database.
The function takes three parameters:

body: A ContactModel object containing the new information for the contact. contact_id: An integer representing the id of an existing contact to be updated. current_user (optional): A User object representing a user who is logged into this application and has been authenticated by FastAPI’s auth middleware, which uses JWT tokens to authenticate users and verify their identity. This parameter is optional because it will only be used if you are using authentication in your application, which you can enable or disable by setting AUTHENTICATION

Parameters:

  • body – ContactModel: Pass the contact data to be updated

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact to be deleted

  • current_user – User: Access the current user’s information

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The updated contact

async my_contacts.routes.contacts.read_contact(contact_id: int, current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The read_contact function is used to retrieve a single contact from the database. It takes in an integer representing the ID of the contact, and returns a Contact object.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the contact to be read

  • current_user – User: Get the current user from the auth_service

  • db – Session: Get a database session

Returns:

A contact object

async my_contacts.routes.contacts.read_contacts(query: str = Query(None), skip: int = Query(0), limit: int = Query(10), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The read_contacts function is used to retrieve a list of contacts from the database. The function can be called with or without a query parameter, which will search for contacts by name, last name, or email. If no query parameter is provided then all contacts are returned in the response body.

Parameters:

  • query – str: Search for contacts by name, last name, or email

  • description – Describe the endpoint in the openapi documentation

  • name (last) – Search for contacts by last name

  • email&quot;) (or) – Describe the query parameter in the swagger documentation

  • skip – int: Skip a number of records in the database

  • description – Provide a description of the endpoint

  • limit – int: Limit the number of records returned by the function

  • description – Provide a description of the endpoint in the openapi documentation

  • current_user – User: Get the user id from the jwt token

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A list of contacts

REST API routes Users¶

async my_contacts.routes.users.forgot_password(request: Request, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, user_email: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The forgot_password function is used to send a reset password email to the user.

The function takes in the user’s email address and sends an email with a link that allows them to reset their password. If no user exists with that email, then an error message is returned.

Parameters:

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the website

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Run the send_email

  • user_email – str: Get the user email from the request body

  • db – Session: Get a database session

Returns:

A dictionary with the user_email and a detail message

async my_contacts.routes.users.reset_password(token: str, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The reset_password function is used to reset a user’s password.

It takes in the token that was sent to the user’s email address, and uses it to get their email address. Then, it gets the user from the database using their email address. Finally, it returns an HTML template with information about that specific user.

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the email from the token

  • request – Request: Get the request object

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A template response that renders the reset_password

async my_contacts.routes.users.reset_password_post(token: str, request: Request, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, new_password: str = Form(PydanticUndefined), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The reset_password_post function is used to reset a user’s password.

It takes in the token, request, background_tasks, new_password and db as parameters. The token parameter is used to get the email of the user who wants to change their password. The request parameter is used for sending emails with sendgrid. The background_tasks parameter allows us to run tasks in the background using celery (in this case we use it for sending emails). The new_password paramter contains a form that requires input from users when they want to change their passwords (it cannot be empty

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • request – Request: Get the base_url

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • new_password – str: Get the new password from the user

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A userresponse object

async my_contacts.routes.users.update_avatar_user(file: UploadFile = File(PydanticUndefined), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The update_avatar_user function updates the avatar of a user.

Parameters:

  • file – UploadFile: Upload the file to cloudinary

  • current_user – User: Get the current user object

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A userresponse object

REST API service Auth¶

class my_contacts.services.auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

Auth class for handling authentication and token generation.

Attributes:

pwd_context (CryptContext): Password hashing context. SECRET_KEY (str): Secret key for token generation. ALGORITHM (str): Token encoding algorithm. oauth2_scheme (OAuth2PasswordBearer): OAuth2 password bearer scheme.

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = 'super_puper_top_secret'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_access_token method creates a new access token.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the claims to be encoded in the JWT. expires_delta (Optional[float]): An optional parameter specifying how long, in seconds,

the access token should last before expiring. If not specified, it defaults to 20 minutes.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into the jwt

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the access token

Returns:

A jwt token that is encoded with the data passed in as a parameter

async create_email_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶

The create_email_token method takes in a dictionary of data and an optional expires_delta parameter. The method then creates a token that will expire after the specified time period. The token is created using the JWT library, which uses the SECRET_KEY and ALGORITHM to create the token.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes and methods

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into the token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the token

Returns:

A token that is encoded using the json web token (jwt) standard

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_refresh_token method creates a refresh token for the user.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the user’s id and username. expires_delta (Optional[float]): The number of seconds until the token expires, defaults to None.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass the user_id and username of the user to be encoded

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the time until the refresh token expires

Returns:

A refresh token

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str)¶

The decode_refresh_token method is used to decode the refresh token. It takes in a refresh_token as an argument and returns the email of the user if successful. If it fails, it raises an HTTPException with status code 401 (Unauthorized) and detail message &quot;Could not validate credentials&quot;.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • refresh_token – str: Pass in the refresh token that was sent to the client

Returns:

The email of the user if the refresh token is valid

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The get_current_user method is a dependency that will be used in the

protected endpoints. It takes a token as an argument and returns the user if it’s valid, otherwise raises an HTTPException with status code 401.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class

  • token – str: Get the token from the authorization header

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A user object that is stored in the database

async get_email_from_token(token: str)¶

The get_email_from_token method takes a token as an argument and returns the email address associated with that token. The method uses the jwt library to decode the token, which is then used to return the email address.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the current object

  • token – str: Pass in the token that is sent to the user’s email

Returns:

The email address of the user who is trying to log in

async get_password_hash(password: str)¶

The get_password_hash method takes a password as input and returns the hashed version of that password. The hashing algorithm used is PBKDF2, which is considered secure for most applications.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • password – str: Pass in the password that is to be hashed

Returns:

A password hash

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
async verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password)¶

The verify_password method takes a plain-text password and a hashed password and returns True if the passwords match, False otherwise. The method uses the passlib library to verify that the hash matches what is stored in our database.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • plain_password – Store the password that is entered by the user

  • hashed_password – Compare the hashed password stored in the database with the plain text password entered by a user

Returns:

True if the plain password matches the hashed password, and false otherwise

REST API service Send email¶

async my_contacts.services.send_email.send_email(email_address: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶

The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link that they can click on to verify their email address. The function takes in three parameters:

-email_address: The user’s email address, which is used as the recipient of the message. -username: The username of the user, which is used in both the subject line and body of the message. -host: The hostname (or IP) where this service is running, which will be included in a link that users can click on

to verify their account.

Parameters:

  • email_address – EmailStr: Validate the email address

  • username – str: Pass the username to the email template

  • host – str: Pass the host url to the template

Returns:

A coroutine object

async my_contacts.services.send_email.send_reset_password_email(email_address: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶

The send_reset_password_email function sends an email to the user with a link to reset their password. The function takes in three arguments:

  • email_address: The user’s email address, which is used as the recipient of the message.

  • username: The username of the account that requested a password reset. This is included in

    the body of the message so that users can be sure they are requesting a password reset for their own account and not someone else’s. It also helps prevent phishing attacks, since it makes it harder for attackers to impersonate other users by sending them fake emails from our service asking

Parameters:

  • email_address – EmailStr: Validate the email address

  • username – str: Send the username to the email template

  • host – str: Create the link to reset the password

Returns:

A token_verification object

async my_contacts.services.send_email.send_success_changed_email(email_address: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_success_changed_email function sends an email to the user’s email address

with a message that their password has been changed.

Parameters:

  • email_address – EmailStr: Validate the email address

  • username – str: Send the username to the email template

  • host – str: Pass the hostname of the server to the email template

Returns:

A coroutine
